c.t: Chapter 09 Disciplinary Sanctions and Monetary Penalties

c.x: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
"Board" means the State Board of Social Work Examiners.
"License" means a license issued by the Board to practice social work.
"Licensee" means a social worker who is licensed by the Board to practice s
"Penalty" means monetary penalty.
“Sanction” means a formal disciplinary action against a license such as a r
Terms Defined.

c.t: .03 Imposition of a Penalty after a Hearing.

c.x: Instead of, or in addition to, suspending the license; or
In addition to revoking the license.

c.t: .04 Guidelines for Disciplinary Sanctions and Imposition of Penalties.

c.x: Subject to the provisions of this section, the Board may impose sanctions a
If a licensee is found in violation of more than one category enumerated in
Notwithstanding the guidelines set forth in this chapter, in order to resol
A departure from the guidelines set forth in this chapter alone is not grou

c.t: .05 Mitigating and Aggravating Factors to be Considered in the Assessment of the Sanction.

c.x: The licensee’s lack of a prior disciplinary record;
The licensee self-reported the violation to the Board;
The licensee’s full and voluntary admissions of misconduct to the Board and
Implementation of remedial measures to correct or mitigate harm arising fro
Timely good-faith effort to make restitution or to rectify consequences of
Evidence of rehabilitation or rehabilitative potential;
Absence of premeditation to commit the misconduct;
Absence of potential harm to public or adverse impact; and
The licensee’s conduct was an isolated incident and not likely to recur.
Mitigating Factors:
The licensee has a previous criminal or administrative disciplinary history
The violation was committed deliberately or with gross negligence or reckle
The violation had the potential for, or caused, serious patient or public h
The violation was part of a pattern of detrimental conduct;
The licensee was motivated to perform the violation for financial gain;
The vulnerability of the clients;
The licensee lacked insight into the wrongfulness of the conduct;
The licensee committed the violation under the guise of treatment; and
Previous attempts at rehabilitation of the licensee were unsuccessful.
Aggravating Factors:
The existence of one or more of these factors does not impose on the Board
